content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are provided a markdown document `md` with julia language code blocks. Write a function `extract_julia_code` that extracts all the code blocks, removes code fences and joins the code blocks (if there are multiple) together with a newline. Return a String. Do not provide any examples.

In Julia, you can use the LightXML package to parse and work with XML documents like Markdown. Here's how you might define `extract_julia_code` function:

Firstly, make sure you have installed the LightXML package using this command in your julia REPL:
```julia
using Pkg
Pkg.add("LightXML")
```

Then, use the following code to define the `extract_julia_code` function:

```julia
using LightXML

function extract_julia_code(md::String)::String
    xdoc = parse_string(md)
    xroot = root(xdoc)
    code_blocks = find_elements(xroot, "pre") # assuming code blocks are within <pre> tags
    code = ""
    for block in code_blocks
        # Check if the code block is julia code by verifying if it has a 'language-julia' attribute
        lang = attribute(block, "class")
        if lang != nothing && occursin("language-julia", lang)
            content = strip(content(block))  # remove leading/trailing spaces
            code *= "$content\n"             # append with a newline
        end
    end
    free(xdoc)  # don't forget to free the document to avoid memory leaks
    return code[1:end-1]  # return without the trailing newline
end
```

Note that this function assumes that julia code blocks are enclosed in `<pre>` tags with `class="language-julia"`. This is how code blocks are usually represented in markdown files. If your input format differs, you might need to adjust the tag and/or attribute names accordingly.

This implementation will extract and concatenate all julia code blocks from a given markdown document. The result will be a single string with newline-separated lines of code.
